awd_titl_txt: Data-driven, biologically constrained computational model of the hippocampal network at full scale
awd_abstract_narration:
Information processing in the brain is organized and facilitated by the complex interactions
of intrinsic biophysical properties of distinct neuronal types, neuronal morphology, and network
connection topology. These properties give rise to specific types of network oscillations
and other dynamic processes that govern neural information encoding and exchange. This project is 
designed to create a detailed picture at unprecedented scale of how the
intrinsic properties of hippocampal principal neurons and interneurons define the network
activity under normal conditions, and how pathological changes in those properties under epileptic
conditions disrupt hippocampal function.  The overarching goal of this activity is to construct
a 1:1 scale, realistic and detailed computational model of the CA1-CA3-dentate gyrus network
in the rat hippocampus and study physiological and pathophysiological network dynamics. 
The project will use the Blue Waters supercomputer to execute this detailed model.

Additionally, the project aims to achieve broader impact in the neuroscience community by providing the
software infrastructure necessary to put unprecedented petascale computing capability within
reach of neuroscientists regardless of their expertise in high-performance computing (HPC).
The support for GPUs and the Intel MIC architecture being developed in the widely-used NEURON
simulator will enable neuroscientists to fully utilize supercomputing accelerator architectures
and thus catalyze greater research productivity and pave the way for wider use of large-scale
and full-scale detailed modeling of the brain.

Furthermore, the neuroscience model code and simulation support software being developed as part of the
research goals behind this proposal will be made publicly available and will remove the
barriers of setting up simulations and managing results data that traditionally have impeded
the utilization of high-performance computing resources.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of the project is to study the mechanisms that govern the emergence of characteristic oscillatory behavior the hippocampal network and its implications for episodic memory using 1:1 scale biophysical computational models approaches that are closely based on electrophysiological, morphological, and imaging data. The hippocampal circuits that store and recall information are comprised of diverse cell types, each exhibiting distinct dynamics and complex patterns of synaptic connectivity.  Computational modeling offers neuroscience a framework to integrate diverse types of data and knowledge, make explicit the assumptions of the conceptual models, and quantitatively predict how each cell type in a neuronal network is expected to respond to specific perturbations. Our computational modeling efforts represent a major milestone in the development of large-scale, anatomically and biophysically realistic models of the brain, as they would allow the generation and testing of hypotheses concerning synaptic and network mechanisms of behaviorally relevant oscillations with unparalleled biological realism, precision and speed.  

We have made major advances towards achieving our aims. Specifically, we have extensively validated the first-of-its-kind 1:1 scale, strictly biological data-driven computational network model of the CA1 region of the rodent hippocampus. The model spontaneously generates theta oscillations, which occur in the brain during locomotion and spatial navigation, and we have simulated a large number of perturbed network configurations in order to determine the range of parameters and conditions that are necessary and sufficient for the emergence of the theta oscillations.

 

We have also recently constructed a full-scale, data-driven model of the dentate gyrus (DG) subregion of the hippocampus, containing over one million neurons. We developed an algorithm to generate realistic GC dendritic morphologies, each with a unique length and branching structure. This approach to modeling neuronal networks with realistic cellular diversity and spatial topography enables us for the first time to ask questions about how spatially localized network events propagate, and how synchronous oscillations are globally coordinated, which are not possible to investigate in simplified models. Handling computational models of this scale has necessitated development of novel strategies and parallel computing-enabled software tools to generate, store, and visualize data specifying neuronal morphologies, and neuronal connectivity. Our DG network model has now been tuned to recapitulate several features of the dynamics of DG neurons measured in vivo, and preliminary results from simulations of realistic spatial input reveal strong rhythmic activity in the DG network, as well as spatially selective firing patterns for a subset of neurons in the network.

The fundamental processes that underlie episodic memory include encoding of relative spatial position, temporal sequencing, and the representation of object location. Therefore, our work on establishing the oscillatory and spatial coding capabilities of detailed, data-driven computational models of the hippocampus provides a key to mechanistic understanding of how cellular, synaptic and network properties interact together to shape memory in the hippocampus.
